title: In the 90s, we were taught to use plastic instead of paper to ... - Reddit
body: Every place you see a plastic bag now had paper bags in the past. The plastic was supposedly better for the environment because paper=pollution in the early 80's. They'd tout the water and energy that goes into it as a waste. They also said Europe had already gone to the plastic bag, which is a standard talking point for anything new to the US.
readable_content:

- SplendidPunkinButter (2018-12-08): I don’t remember being taught that. I remember being taught to recycle paper.
- sarahjeni (2018-12-08): We should start using human skin for all of our carry and storage needs.
- sep31974 (2018-12-08): It's okay to change your opinion based on new facts.
- justimari (2018-12-08): Honestly just carry around a reusable bag. That’s the only way to not mess anything up
- HuxleysHero (2018-12-08): Who taught you to use plastic? We knew plastic was bad back then too, and we cut 6-pack rings to keep them from killing sea life.

summary:
The conversation reflects a mixture of skepticism, disbelief, and a call for sustainable solutions regarding the use of plastic and paper. The comments highlight a range of opinions, from questioning the educational messages of the past to advocating for more environmentally friendly practices. Overall, there is a sense of awareness and concern about the environmental impact of plastic and paper use.
